AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: American Linden, also called Basswood, is a tall tree with high-arching branches and a relatively small crown. The shape and large size of its leaves is distinctive. It's often codominant in late-successional forests with sugar maple and red oak. The common name of basswood is derived from bastwood, in reference to the tough inner bark (bast) which has been used to make rope and mats. Trees are commercially harvested, particularly in the Great Lakes region, for their light wood which is used to make such items as furniture, shipping crates, boxes, and veneer. Common name of linden plus the family name of Linneaus (famous Swedish botanist Carl Linnaeus was ennobled as Carl von Linne) both derive from lind which is the Swedish word for a linden tree.
Gray to brown, broken into many long, narrow, flat-topped, scaly ridges, very tough and fibrous
Perfect, pale yellow, 1/2" wide, fragrant, borne in 5-10 flowered, 2 to 3" wide pendulous cymes in mid to late June
Spherical, woody, nut like drupe, -9 mm in diameter, minutely hairy, maturing in August

Alternate, simple, broad ovate, 4-8" long, almost as wide, abruptly acuminate, cordate to truncate at base, coarsely serrate with long-pointed teeth, dark green and glabrous above, light green beneath with tufts of hair in the axil of the lateral veins, wanting at base

ThemeEntityData.Description: American Linden, also called Basswood, is a tall tree with high-arching branches and a relatively small crown. The shape and large size of its leaves is distinctive. It's often codominant in late-successional forests with sugar maple and red oak. The common name of basswood is derived from bastwood, in reference to the tough inner bark (bast) which has been used to make rope and mats. Trees are commercially harvested, particularly in the Great Lakes region, for their light wood which is used to make such items as furniture, shipping crates, boxes, and veneer. Common name of linden plus the family name of Linneaus (famous Swedish botanist Carl Linnaeus was ennobled as Carl von Linne) both derive from lind which is the Swedish word for a linden tree.
